The term 'illicit label' is defined as a genuine certificate or similar labeling component used by the copyright owner to verify authenticity without authorization. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits unauthorized distribution of counterfeit labels or documentation for copyrighted works. This includes falsifying genuine certificates to designate more licensed users or copies than authorized by the copyright owner. Counterfeit documentation or packaging refers to items that appear genuine but are not. Counterfeit documentation or packaging that appears genuine but is not includes items like copyrighted sound recordings, computer programs, motion pictures, literary works, and visual arts. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits unauthorized distribution of counterfeit labels or documentation for copyrighted works, including falsifying genuine certificates. This includes items like copyrighted sound recordings, computer programs, motion pictures, literary works, and visual arts. The Act also includes provisions for civil remedies related to counterfeit labels and illicit labels. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" allows copyright owners to seek civil remedies in court for violations of unauthorized distribution of counterfeit labels or documentation for copyrighted works. This includes obtaining injunctions to prevent further violations. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" allows copyright owners to seek civil remedies in court for violations of unauthorized distribution of counterfeit labels or documentation for copyrighted works. The court may order the impounding of any article involved in the violation and award the injured party attorney fees, costs, actual damages, additional profits, or statutory damages. The injured party can recover actual damages and profits from a violator of copyright laws. Actual damages are calculated by multiplying the value of the infringing materials. The value of infringing materials can be calculated by considering the number and value of phonorecords, copies, or works of visual art with counterfeit labels or packaging. The value of a phonorecord, copy, or work of visual art is determined by the retail value of an authorized copy of the copyrighted material, such as sound recordings, musical works, computer programs, motion pictures, audiovisual works, and literary works. The injured party may choose to receive statutory damages instead of actual damages and profits for copyright violations, ranging from $2,500 to $25,000 per violation. The value of a copyrighted work is based on the retail value of an authorized copy. The court may award damages exceeding $25,000 for copyright violations, with the possibility of tripling the amount for subsequent violations within 3 years. A civil action must be initiated within 3 years of discovering the violation. The item relating to section 2318 in the table of sections for chapter 113 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to read as follows: "2318. Trafficking in counterfeit labels, illicit labels, or counterfeit documentation or packaging." SEC. 103. OTHER RIGHTS NOT AFFECTED. The amendments made by this title do not affect liability under certain sections of Title 17, United States Code, and do not apply to electronic transmissions of specific documents described in Title 18, United States Code. The amendments made by this title do not affect liability under certain sections of Title 17, United States Code, and do not apply to electronic transmissions of counterfeit labels or documentation defined in Title 18, United States Code. Fair use of genuine certificates and similar components is preserved. TITLE II--FRAUDULENT ONLINE IDENTITY SANCTIONS

This title is known as the "Fraudulent Online Identity Sanctions Act" and includes an amendment to the Trademark Act of 1946. Section 35 of the Trademark Act of 1946 is amended to include a rebuttable presumption of willful violation if false contact information is knowingly provided in cases of trademark infringement. The Trademark Act of 1946 is amended to include a presumption of willful violation if false contact information is provided when registering a domain name. SEC. 203. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 17, UNITED STATES CODE. Section 504(c) of title 17, United States Code is amended to include a rebuttable presumption of willful infringement if false contact information is knowingly provided in connection with a domain name used for infringement. The term 'domain name' in this paragraph refers to the definition in the Trademark Act of 1946, with no limitations on willful infringement under this subsection. SEC. 204. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 18, UNITED STATES CODE. Sentencing Enhancement: If a defendant convicted of a felony offense knowingly falsely registered a domain name and used it in the course of the offense, the maximum imprisonment for that offense will be doubled or increased by 7 years. "Falsely registers" means registering in a way that prevents identification or contact with the person who registers. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and enforce sentencing enhancements for individuals convicted of felony offenses involving falsely registered domain names. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines to ensure stricter penalties for felony offenses committed online using a domain name with false contact information. The United States Sentencing Commission will review sentencing guidelines to impose harsher penalties for felony offenses committed online with a domain name registered using false contact information. The term "domain name" is defined in the Trademark Act of 1946. SEC. 205 of the text states that nothing in the title shall affect free speech or press rights related to domain name registration. It also clarifies that courts have discretion in determining damages, relief, and terms of imprisonment for intellectual property rights infringement offenses. TITLE III--COURTS

SEC. 301. ADDITIONAL PLACE OF HOLDING COURT IN THE DISTRICT OF COLORADO.

Section 85 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include "Colorado Springs," after "Boulder,".

SEC. 302. PLACE OF HOLDING COURT IN THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF NEW YORK.

Section 112(a) of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include "Plattsburgh," after "Malone,".
